author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Ex-anchor, boyfriend of slain journalist leaves TV for politics
text:
A Virginia news anchor whose girlfriend was fatally shot during a live 2015 interview announced he’s leaving television to run for office.
Chris Hurst, 28, anchored his last WDBJ-TV newscast Thursday, telling viewers about his departure and how grateful he has been for the love and support the community showed him since the death of his girlfriend, 24-year-old reporter Alison Parker, and co-worker, 27-year-old Adam Ward, on Aug. 26, 2015.
“In one moment, my life, my direction, and my mission changed forever,” Hurst said on air. “I don’t know what my future holds. I only know that I’m being called to something greater, that I need to move on to a new chapter, one that has not yet been written. Be assured, however, that you will see me again in whatever new path I decide to take.”
Slain TV reporter Alison Parker and boyfriend Chris Hurst planned to get married before she was fatally shot during a live interview on Aug. 26. 2015. (Facebook) Hurst told the Roanoke Times  he’s running for as a Democratic for 12th District because he wants to tackle a variety of issues, particularly gun control, to ensure the safety of his community. The slain journalist’s father, Andy Parker, also called for stronger gun control laws .
Senate unanimously confirms David Shulkin as Trump’s VA secretary 
Hurst said he and Parker had been dating for nine months and planned to wed.
Chris Hurst is seen holding a photo album that was created by fellow reporter and girlfriend Alison Parker in 2015. (Erica Yoon/AP) Ex-WBDJ colleague, Vester Lee Flanagan II, 41, opened fire at Parker and Ward during a live interview at Smith Mountain Lake and then uploaded a video of the killings to social media before shooting himself in his car.
“Chris informed us that he is running for political office and can no longer serve as an on-air news anchor. We wish Chris well and thank him for his years here at Your Hometown Station,” WDBJ General Manager Matt Puno said in an email to staffers, according to Adweek .
Hurst — who was born and raised in Philadelphia — joined the station in 2010 as a reporter covering crime and courts and also reported on special assignments about mental health. He became an anchor the following year.
